_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Frozen Fruit, Juice, and Vegetable Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Hancock Foods Inc. Executive Summary Report

1.     Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
We at Hancock Foods Inc. are strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.


2.    The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled
Our facility's primary activity is blast freezing freshly harvested blueberries.  The berries are then stored in a cold storage Freezer. We have 1 regulated substance present at our facility.  This is Anhydrous Ammonia, and is used as a refrigerant for both the Blast Freezing Process, and the cold storage area. 


3.    The Worst Case Release Scenario and the Alternative Release Scenario, including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario
To evaluate the worst-case scenario, and alternate release scenario, we have used the RMP Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration Reference Tables or Equations. The following paragraph provides details of the chosen scenarios.

The worst-case release scenario submitted for Program 2 and 3 toxic substances as a class involves a catastrophic release from the refrigeration systems largest liquid receiver.  In this scenario 9800lbs. of Ammonia (anhydrous) is released.  The toxic liquid released is assumed to form a 1 cm deep pool from which evaporation takes place.  The entire pool is estimated to evaporate over 10 minutes.  At Class F atmospheric stability and 1.5 m/s wind speed, the maximum distance of 1.42 miles is obtained corresponding to a toxic endpoint of 0.14 mg/L.

The alternative release scenario for Ammonia (anhydrous) involves a release from Imeco High Pressure Receiver.  The scenario involves the release of 1000 lbs. of ammonia. Toxic liquid is assumed to be released to form a 1 cm deep pool from which evaporation takes place.  The entire pool is estimated to have evaporated after 10 minutes. Under neutral

weather conditions, the maximum distance to the toxic endpoint of 0.14 mg/L of Ammonia (anhydrous) is 0.09 miles.


4.    The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
Our facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR part 68 of the EPA.  This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with NFPA-58 Standard, 1967 Edition. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at our stationary source.

Process Safety Information
Hancock Foods Inc. maintains a record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all refrigeration operations. 

Process Hazard Analysis
Our facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes have been identified and controlled efficiently.  The methodology used to carry out the process hazard analysis was the ?What If Checklist? format.  A third a third party consultant who acted as team leader, as well as our plant team who are qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and the operation s of the refrigeration operation undertook the study. The study is updated according to regulated intervals. 



Operating Procedures
For the purposes of safely conducting activities within our facility, Hancock Foods Inc. maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes. This information is sometimes used as training material. 

Training
Hancock Foods Inc. has a training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating the process are competent.  Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed. Training consists of on the job, hands on training. Operators mus

t demonstrate competency in order to pass.

Mechanical Integrity
Hancock Foods Inc. carries out maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others; pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  All checks are documented and stored. Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.  

Management of Change
Written procedures are in place at Hancock Foods Inc. to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  The management of change program is reviewed often, most recently 8/25/04. In the past 5 years Hancock Foods has not made any process changes that would facilitate the use of the management of change process. 

Pre-startup Reviews
Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice at Hancock Foods Inc.  The most recent review was performed in July of 2004. Each year before the start up of the York Blast tunnel regular pre start up procedure and reviews are strictly adhered to. These reviews are conducted to confirm that equipment, and operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits
Hancock Foods Inc. conducts audits to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented.  The most recent compliance audit was conducted in March of 1999.  

Incident Investigation
Hancock Foods Inc. promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to

prevent the release from reoccurring. Hancock Foods has not experienced any incidents in the past 5 years.   

Employee Participation
Hancock Foods Inc. believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular.






Contractors
On occasion, Hancock Foods Inc. hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, an evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out.  Hancock Foods Inc. has a policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related the contractor's work and the processes.  Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.

5.    Five-year Accident History
Hancock Foods Inc. has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last 5 years.  Due to our stringent release prevention policies, there have been 0 recordable releases within the last 5 years.

6.    Emergency Response Plan
Hancock Foods Inc. has an emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including evacuations, and notification of local emergency response agencies and the public. Hancock County LEPC is the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) with which our emergency plan has been coordinated and verified. The Emergency Response Plan was last updated in July of 2004. 

7.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of our accidental release prevention program.  Hancock Fo

ods is considering several areas to enhance Safety. Hancock Foods is considering sending system operators to Ammonia Operator Training classes. Hancock Foods is also considering the possibility of installing a Computerized Maintenance Management System. A CMM System will assist Hancock Foods in assuring that all maintenance procedures are carried out in a timely fashion
